subsection.text: Real property used as the principal family residence by a husband and wife and held by the husband and wife as tenants by the entirety may not be forfeited unless:

paragraph.text: the property was used in connection with a violation of §§ 5-602 through 5-609, §§ 5-612 through 5-614, § 5-617, § 5-618, or § 5-628 of the Criminal Law Article or with an attempt or conspiracy to violate Title 5 of the Criminal Law Article; and

both the husband and wife are convicted of a violation of §§ 5-602 through 5-609, §§ 5-612 through 5-614, § 5-617, § 5-618, or § 5-628 of the Criminal Law Article or of an attempt or conspiracy to violate Title 5 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: A Schedule I substance listed in § 5-402 of the Criminal Law Article shall be seized and summarily forfeited to the State if the substance is:

paragraph.text: possessed, transferred, sold, or offered for sale in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law; or
possessed by the State and its owner is not known.

subsection.text: A plant may be seized and summarily forfeited to the State if the plant:

paragraph.text: is one from which a Schedule I or Schedule II substance listed in § 5-402 or § 5-403 of the Criminal Law Article may be derived; and

subparagraph.text: has been planted or cultivated in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law;
has an unknown owner or cultivator; or
is a wild growth.

subsection.text: The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene may seize and subject a plant to forfeiture if the person that occupies or controls the place where the plant is growing or being stored fails, on demand from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, to produce an appropriate registration or proof that the person is the holder of a registration.
Property subject to forfeiture under this title may be seized:

paragraph.text: on a warrant issued by a court that has jurisdiction over the property; and
without a warrant when:

subparagraph.text: the seizure is incident to an arrest or a search under a search warrant;
the seizure is incident to an inspection under an administrative inspection warrant;
the property subject to seizure has been the subject of a prior judgment in favor of the State in a criminal injunction or forfeiture proceeding under this title;
there is probable cause to believe that the property is directly or indirectly dangerous to health or safety; or
there is probable cause to believe that the property has been used or is intended to be used in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law or this title.

subsection.text: The seizing authority that seizes money that is contraband shall immediately:

paragraph.text: photograph the contraband money and record the quantity of each denomination of coin or currency seized; and
deposit the money to the account of the appropriate local financial authority.

subsection.text: A photograph taken under subsection (b) of this section may be substituted for money as evidence in a criminal or forfeiture proceeding.
Property seized under this title:

paragraph.text: is not repleviable; but
is in the custody of the seizing authority, subject only to the orders, judgments, and decrees of the court or the official having jurisdiction over the property.

subsection.text: A seizing authority may place seized property under seal and remove the property to a place designated by the court.
In exercising the authority to seize motor vehicles under this title, a seizing authority shall apply the standards listed in subsection (b) of this section.
A motor vehicle used in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law or this title shall be seized and forfeiture shall be recommended to the forfeiting authority if:

paragraph.text: any quantity of a controlled dangerous substance is sold or attempted to be sold in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law or this title;

an amount of the controlled dangerous substance or paraphernalia is found that reasonably shows that the violator intended to sell the controlled dangerous substance in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law; or
the total circumstances of the case as listed in subsection (c) of this section dictate that seizure and forfeiture are justified.

subsection.text: Circumstances to be considered in deciding whether seizure and forfeiture are justified include:

paragraph.text: the possession of controlled dangerous substances;
an extensive criminal record of the violator;
a previous conviction of the violator for a controlled dangerous substances crime;
evidence that the motor vehicle was acquired by use of proceeds from a transaction involving a controlled dangerous substance;
circumstances of the arrest; and
the way in which the motor vehicle was used.

section.text: A motor vehicle used in violation of this title may not be seized and forfeiture may not be recommended to the forfeiting authority if:

paragraph.text: the motor vehicle falls within § 12-103(b) of this title;

subparagraph.text: an innocent registered owner lends the motor vehicle to another person; and
that person, or someone invited into the motor vehicle by that person, brings a controlled dangerous substance or paraphernalia into the motor vehicle without the registered owner’s knowledge; or

a member of the family other than the registered owner uses the motor vehicle, and a controlled dangerous substance or paraphernalia is in the motor vehicle in an amount insufficient to suggest a sale is contemplated;
a sale was not made or attempted; and
the registered owner did not know that the controlled dangerous substance or paraphernalia was in the motor vehicle.

subsection.text: The chief law enforcement officer of the seizing authority that seizes a motor vehicle used in violation of this title shall recommend to the appropriate forfeiting authority in writing that the motor vehicle be forfeited only if the officer:

paragraph.text: determines from the records of the Motor Vehicle Administration the names and addresses of all registered owners and secured parties as defined in the Code;
personally reviews the facts and circumstances of the seizure; and
personally determines, according to the standards listed in § 12-204(b) of this subtitle, and represents in writing that forfeiture is warranted.
A sworn affidavit by the chief law enforcement officer that the officer followed the requirements of this paragraph is admissible in evidence in a proceeding under this section.

The chief law enforcement officer may not be subpoenaed or compelled to appear and testify if another law enforcement officer with personal knowledge of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure and the recommendation of forfeiture appears and testifies at the proceeding.

subsection.text: The forfeiting authority shall surrender the motor vehicle on request to the owner if the forfeiting authority determines, independent of the decision of the seizing authority, that:

paragraph.text: the motor vehicle falls within the purview of § 12-205 of this subtitle; or
the standards listed under § 12-204(b) of this subtitle were not met.

subsection.text: In a proceeding under this title, the court may determine, based on the standards listed in § 12-204(b) of this subtitle, whether the seizing authority or forfeiting authority abused its discretion or was clearly erroneous:

paragraph.text: in recommending the forfeiture of a motor vehicle; or
in not surrendering on request a motor vehicle to an owner.

Except as provided in §§ 12-209 and 12-210 of this subtitle, an owner of seized property who wishes to obtain possession of the property, to convey an interest in real property, or to remove a building or fixture from real property shall notify the clerk of the proper court.
If forfeiture proceedings have begun, the proper court is the court where the proceedings have begun.
If criminal proceedings have begun but forfeiture proceedings have not begun, the proper court is the court where the criminal proceedings have begun.
If neither forfeiture nor criminal proceedings have begun, the proper court is the circuit court for the county where the property was seized.
Unless the forfeiting authority and the owner agree to a bond in another amount, if a motor vehicle is not needed for evidentiary purposes in a judicial proceeding:

subparagraph.text: the court shall appraise the value of the motor vehicle on the basis of the average value of the motor vehicle set forth in the National Automobile Dealer’s Association official used car guide; or

if the owner shows that a lien is on the motor vehicle and the owner agrees to make the required payments to the lienholder, the court shall require a bond in an amount of the average value of the motor vehicle set forth in the National Automobile Dealer’s Association official used car guide, less the amount owed on the lien.

paragraph.text: For a motor vehicle, the court shall appraise the value in the manner provided in this subsection and provide the appraisal in writing to the clerk of the court.
If property other than a motor vehicle is not needed for evidentiary purposes in a judicial proceeding, the clerk shall obtain an independent appraisal of the value of the property.
The sheriff or other person responsible for an appraisal under this subsection shall promptly:

subparagraph.text: inspect and appraise the value of the property; and
return the appraisal in writing under oath to the clerk of the court.

subsection.text: Notice of the appraisal shall be sent to all lienholders shown in the records required by law for notice or the perfection of the lien.

paragraph.text: On the filing of an appraisal, the owner may give bond payable to the clerk of the court in an amount equal to the greater of:

subparagraph.text: the appraised value of the property plus any accrued costs; or
the aggregate amount of the liens on the property that are shown in the records required by law for the notice or perfection of liens.

paragraph.text: A person may give a bond under this section by cash, through a surety, through a lien on real property, or by other means that the clerk approves.
A bond authorized under this section:

subparagraph.text: shall be conditioned for performance on final judgment by the court;
shall be filed in the District Court or circuit court where the criminal action that gave rise to the seizure is pending; and
unless a complaint for forfeiture has been filed, shall be part of the same criminal proceeding.

paragraph.text: If a criminal action is not pending or a forfeiture complaint has not been filed, the bond shall be filed in the circuit court or District Court where the property was seized.

If the court orders that property or an interest or equity in the property or proceeds be forfeited under this title, the court shall enter judgment in the amount of the bond against the obligors on the bond without further proceedings.
Payment of the amount of the bond shall be applied as provided under § 12-402(d)(2) of this title.

section.text: Seizure of real property occurs on the earlier of the filing:

paragraph.text: of a complaint for forfeiture under this title; or
of a notice of pending litigation in the circuit court of the county where the real property is located.

subsection.text: Subject to the rights of a lienholder to sell the real property, an owner or owner’s tenant may remain in possession of seized real property until forfeiture is ordered.
The forfeiting authority may apply to the court for the appointment of a receiver to apply income from income-producing property.

If a person who is an owner or owner’s tenant remains in possession of the real property and the person’s interest in the real property is forfeited, the person shall immediately surrender the real property to the seizing authority in substantially the same condition as when seized.
This section does not apply if:

paragraph.text: an act is agreed to by a forfeiting authority or is ordered by the court; or
an owner posts a bond under § 12-208 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (a) of this section, until the court enters judgment in favor of the owner, an owner may not attempt:

paragraph.text: to convey or encumber an interest in seized real property; or
to remove a building or fixture on seized real property.

section.text: Except as provided in § 12-304(c) of this subtitle, if property is seized under § 12-202(a)(2)(iv) and (v) of this title because there is probable cause to believe that the property is directly or indirectly dangerous to health or safety and that the property was or will be used to violate this title, forfeiture proceedings under this subtitle shall be filed promptly.

subsection.text: To apply for the forfeiture of money, the appropriate local financial authority or the Attorney General shall file a complaint and affidavit in the District Court or the circuit court for the county in which the money was seized.
The complaint and affidavit shall be served in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

section.text: Except as provided in § 12-302 of this subtitle and § 4-401(9) of the Courts Article, the appropriate forfeiting authority shall file proceedings under this title in the circuit court.

subsection.text: Except as provided under subsections (b) and (c) of this section, a complaint seeking forfeiture shall be filed within the earlier of:

paragraph.text: 90 days after the seizure; or
1 year after the final disposition of the criminal charge for the violation giving rise to the forfeiture.

subsection.text: A complaint for the forfeiture of a motor vehicle shall be filed within 45 days after the motor vehicle is seized.

paragraph.text: A proceeding about money shall be filed within 90 days after the final disposition of criminal proceedings that arise out of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law.
If the State or a political subdivision does not file proceedings about money within the 90-day period, the money seized under this title shall be returned to the owner on request by the owner.
If the owner fails to ask the return of the money within 1 year after the final disposition of criminal proceedings, as provided under § 12-403 of this title, the money shall revert to:

subparagraph.text: the political subdivision in which the money was seized; or
the State, if the money was seized by State authorities.

subsection.text: A complaint seeking forfeiture shall contain:

paragraph.text: a description of the property seized;
the date and place of the seizure;
the name of the owner, if known;
the name of the person in possession, if known;
the name of each lienholder, if known or reasonably subject to discovery;
an allegation that the property is subject to forfeiture;

if the forfeiting authority seeks to forfeit a lienholder’s interest in property, an allegation that the lien was created with actual knowledge that the property was being or was to be used in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law;
a statement of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure;
a statement setting forth the specific grounds for forfeiture; and
an oath or affirmation by the forfeiting authority that the contents of the complaint are true to the best of the forfeiting authority’s knowledge, information, and belief.

subsection.text: Within 20 days after the filing of the complaint, copies of the summons and complaint shall be sent by certified mail requesting “restricted delivery – show to whom, date, address of delivery” and first–class mail to all known owners and lienholders whose identities are reasonably subject to discovery, including all real property owners and lienholders shown in the records required by law for notice or perfection of the lien.
A notice shall be signed by the clerk and shall:

paragraph.text: include the caption of the case;
describe the substance of the complaint and the relief sought;
state the latest date on which a response may be filed;
state that the property shall be forfeited if a response is not filed on time;
state that the owner of the property may have possession of the property pending forfeiture by posting a bond as provided in § 12-208 of this title; and
tell where to file a response and whom to contact for more information concerning the forfeiture.

subsection.text: Within 20 days after the filing of the complaint, the notice shall be:

paragraph.text: posted by the sheriff on the door of the courthouse where the action is pending or on a bulletin board within the immediate vicinity of the door;
posted by the sheriff in a conspicuous place on the land, if forfeiture of real property is sought; and

published at least once a week in each of 3 successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in the county in which the action is pending, unless the property is a boat or motor vehicle.

section.text: The answer to a complaint shall:

paragraph.text: comply with the Maryland Rules;
state the nature and extent of the person’s right in, title to, or interest in the property;
state how and when the person acquired a right in, title to, or interest in the property; and
contain a request for relief and a request for a prompt hearing.

subsection.text: If an answer has been filed on time, the court shall set a hearing on the forfeiture claim within 60 days after the later of:

paragraph.text: posting of notice under § 12-306(b)(1) or (2) of this subtitle; or
final publication of notice under § 12-306(b)(3) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Without a hearing, the court may order forfeiture of the property interest of a person who fails to timely file an answer.

section.text: Except as provided in §§ 12-103(e) and 12-312 of this title, an owner’s interest in real property may be forfeited if the real property was used in connection with a violation of §§ 5-602 through 5-609, §§ 5-612 through 5-614, § 5-617, § 5-618, or § 5-628 of the Criminal Law Article or is convicted of an attempt or conspiracy to violate Title 5 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: Forfeiture proceedings for real property may be brought in the jurisdiction where:

paragraph.text: the criminal charges are pending;
the owner resides; or
the real property is located.

If forfeiture proceedings for real property are brought in a jurisdiction other than where the real property is located, a notice of pending litigation shall be filed in the jurisdiction where the property is located.
A notice of pending litigation required under this subsection shall include at least:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the owner of the real property;
a description of the real property; and
a description of the reasons for the filing of the forfeiture proceedings and notice of pending litigation.

section.text: If an owner of real property used as the principal family residence is convicted under §§ 5-602 through 5-609, §§ 5-612 through 5-614, § 5-617, § 5-618, or § 5-628 of the Criminal Law Article or is convicted of an attempt or conspiracy to violate Title 5 of the Criminal Law Article and the owner files an appeal of the conviction, the court shall stay forfeiture proceedings under § 12-103(e) or § 12-312(b) of this title against the real property during the pendency of the appeal.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, there is a rebuttable presumption that property or part of a property in which a person has an ownership interest is subject to forfeiture as proceeds, if the State establishes by clear and convincing evidence that:

subparagraph.text: the person has violated §§ 5-602 through 5-609, §§ 5-612 through 5-614, § 5-617, § 5-618, or § 5-628 of the Criminal Law Article or has attempted or conspired to violate Title 5 of the Criminal Law Article;
the property was acquired by the person during the violation or within a reasonable time after the violation; and
there was no other likely source for the property.

paragraph.text: A claimant of the property has the burden of proof to rebut the presumption in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Real property used as the principal family residence may not be forfeited under this section unless:

paragraph.text: an owner of the real property was convicted of a crime described under subsection (a)(1) of this section; or
the real property is covered by § 12-103(d)(2) of this title.

section.text: In a proceeding under this title, a court:

paragraph.text: may grant requests for mitigation or remission of forfeiture or take other action that protects the rights of innocent persons, is consistent with this title, and is in the interest of justice;
may resolve claims arising under this title; and
may take appropriate measures to safeguard and maintain property forfeited under this title pending the disposition of the property.

subsection.text: After a full hearing, if the court determines that the property should not be forfeited, the court shall order that the property be released.
Subject to § 12-403(b) of this subtitle, if the court determines that the property should be forfeited, the court shall order that the property be forfeited to the appropriate governing body.

If the court determines that the forfeited property is subject to a valid lien created without actual knowledge of the lienholder that the property was being or was to be used in violation of the Controlled Dangerous Substances law, the court shall order that the property be released within 5 days to the first priority lienholder.

paragraph.text: The lienholder shall sell the property in a commercially reasonable manner.
The proceeds of the sale shall be applied as follows:

subparagraph.text: to the court costs of the forfeiture proceeding;
to the balance due the lienholder, including all reasonable costs incident to the sale;
to payment of all other expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture, including expenses of seizure or maintenance of custody; and
except as provided in § 12-403(b) of this subtitle, to the General Fund of the State or of the political subdivision that seized the property.

paragraph.text: Whenever property is forfeited under this title, the governing body where the property was seized may:

subparagraph.text: keep the property for official use;
require an appropriate unit to take custody of the property and destroy or otherwise dispose of it; or
sell the property if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the law does not require the property to be destroyed; and
the property is not harmful to the public.

paragraph.text: The proceeds of a sale under this subsection shall first be used to pay all proper expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture and sale, including expenses of seizure, maintenance of custody, advertising, and court costs.

subsection.text: If the seizing authority was a State law enforcement unit:

paragraph.text: under § 12-402(b) of this subtitle, the court shall order the property to be forfeited to the State law enforcement unit; or
under § 12-402(d)(2)(iv) of this subtitle, the proceeds of the sale shall be paid to the State law enforcement unit.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the State law enforcement unit that receives forfeited property or proceeds from a sale of forfeited property under this section shall:

paragraph.text: dispose of the forfeited property as provided in subsection (a) of this section; and
pay to the General Fund of the State any proceeds of the sale of the forfeited property.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided under federal law, a law enforcement unit other than a State law enforcement unit that participated with a State law enforcement unit in seizing property forfeited under this section:

paragraph.text: shall be paid by the State law enforcement unit the share of the proceeds from the sale of the forfeited property as agreed by the law enforcement units; or
may ask the Governor’s Office of Crime Control and Prevention to determine its share.

subsection.text: Proceeds that a law enforcement unit other than a State law enforcement unit receives under subsection (d) of this section shall be deposited in the general fund of the political subdivision of that law enforcement unit.

section.text: A sale of property ordered under this title shall be made for cash and gives the purchaser clear and absolute title.

subsection.text: Before exercising the right to sell property that has been seized under this title, a lienholder shall give to the forfeiting authority:

paragraph.text: written notice of the intention to sell;
copies of documents giving rise to the lien;
an affidavit under oath by the lienholder:

subparagraph.text: stating that the underlying obligation is in default; and
stating the reasons for the default.

subsection.text: On request of the lienholder, the forfeiting authority shall release the property to the lienholder.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the law governing the sale of collateral securing an obligation in default governs a lienholder’s repossession and sale of property that has been seized under this title.
A lienholder may not be required to take possession of the property before the sale of the property.
Any part of the proceeds from a sale of property that has been seized under this title that would be paid to an owner of the property under the applicable law relating to distribution of proceeds:

paragraph.text: shall be paid to the seizing authority; and
shall be property subject to forfeiture.

subsection.text: If an order of forfeiture is not entered, the State shall return to the owner that part of the proceeds and any costs of the forfeiture proceedings paid from the proceeds of the sale.

If the interest of the owner in property that has been seized under this title is redeemed, the lienholder shall mail a notice of the redemption to the forfeiting authority within 10 days after the redemption.

paragraph.text: If property that has been seized under this title has been repossessed or otherwise lawfully taken by the lienholder, the lienholder shall return the property to the seizing authority within 21 days after the redemption.
The seizing authority and the forfeiting authority may then proceed with the forfeiture of the property or the proceeds from the sale of the property.

subsection.text: Time limitations required under this title for notice and filing of the complaint for forfeiture run from the date of redemption or purchase of the property that has been seized under this title.

section.text: This title does not prohibit a lienholder from exercising rights under applicable law, including the right to sell property that has been seized under this title, if a default occurs in the obligation giving rise to the lien.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Final disposition” includes an acquittal, dismissal, nolle prosequi, finding of guilty, probation before judgment, plea of guilty or of nolo contendere, marking the charge “stet” on the docket, and an order of an appellate court ending a criminal case.
“Financial authority” means:

paragraph.text: if the seizing authority is the State, the State Treasurer;
if the seizing authority is a unit of a county, the treasurer or director of finance of that county; or
if the seizing authority is a unit of a municipal corporation, the treasurer or director of finance of that municipal corporation.

subsection.text: Money is prima facie contraband if a law enforcement officer in the State seizes the money in connection with an arrest for:

paragraph.text: unlawfully playing or operating a bookmaking scheme;
unlawfully betting on a horse race, athletic event, lottery, or game; or
using an unlawful gaming table or gaming device.
For purposes of this subsection, the Police Department of Baltimore City is not a State authority.
All rights in, title to, and interest in money seized under subsection (a) of this section shall immediately vest in and to:

subparagraph.text: the county or the municipal corporation, if the money is seized by the police of the local government, including a sheriff’s department that is the local law enforcement unit; or
the State, if the money is seized by a State authority.

subsection.text: The seizing authority that seizes money that is contraband shall immediately:

paragraph.text: photograph the money and record the quantity of each denomination of coin or currency seized; and
deposit the money to the account of the financial authority.

subsection.text: A photograph taken under subsection (a) of this section may be substituted for money as evidence in a criminal or forfeiture proceeding.

section.text: Pending final disposition, the financial authority shall account for and deposit seized money in an interest-bearing bank account or invest the seized money in accordance with Article 95 of the Code.

paragraph.text: Each application for the forfeiture of contraband shall be by complaint and shall be filed in the District Court or circuit court of the county in which the contraband was seized.

The complaint shall be served in accordance with Maryland Rule 2-121 or 3-121(a), or if service of process is unable to be made and the summons is returned non est, substitute service may be made in accordance with Maryland Rule 2-122 or 3-121(b) or (c).

If a conviction, including a plea of guilty or plea of nolo contendere, is entered against a person arrested in connection with the seizure of the money, the financial authority shall apply to the District Court or circuit court for an order forfeiting the money to the jurisdiction that the financial authority serves.
The financial authority shall apply for the order within 90 days after entry of the conviction or plea, unless the case is appealed.

subsection.text: Before ordering a forfeiture of the money, the court must be satisfied that no undetermined proceeding to recover the money is pending in court against the financial authority.
Seized money may be returned only as provided in this section.

Subject to subsection (c) of this section, on a final disposition a claimant may ask the appropriate court for a determination that the money is the property of the claimant and an order that the money be returned.
A claimant under subsection (b) of this section must:

paragraph.text: apply within 1 year after the judgment or order was entered or the final disposition was taken; and
give written notice to the financial authority at least 10 days before filing the complaint.

subsection.text: In a proceeding on a complaint for a return of money, an acquittal, dismissal, or nolle prosequi with respect to the gambling charges or indictments involved in the seizure of the money is prima facie evidence that the money is not contraband.
A conviction, plea of guilty or of nolo contendere, or probation under § 6-220 of this article is prima facie evidence that the money is contraband.
Marking a charge “stet” on the docket does not create any presumption as to whether money is contraband.

Subject to subsection (b) of this section, if a complaint is not timely and properly filed or if the action is finally decided against the claimant, the seized money not disposed of shall be forfeited to the custodian without further judicial action.

For the seized money to be forfeited, timely notice must be given by certified mail or other appropriate means to any known claimants, at their last known addresses, of the requirements of this section for making claim for the return of seized money.

section.text: This subtitle does not prohibit the trial judge, after an acquittal or dismissal, from ordering the immediate return of all property seized.
The following property is subject to seizure and forfeiture:

paragraph.text: a handgun worn, carried, or transported in violation of § 4-203 or § 4-204 of the Criminal Law Article or sold, rented, transferred, or possessed in violation of § 5-103, § 5-104, § 5-118, § 5-119, § 5-120, § 5-121, § 5-122, § 5-123, § 5-124, § 5-125, § 5-126, § 5-127, § 5-128, § 5-129, § 5-133(a), (b), and (d), § 5-134, or § 5-136 of the Public Safety Article; and
ammunition, handgun parts, or handgun appurtenances that are:

subparagraph.text: worn, carried, or transported in violation of § 4-203 or § 4-204 of the Criminal Law Article; or
found in the immediate vicinity of a handgun worn, carried, or transported in violation of § 4-203 or § 4-204 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: An authorized law enforcement officer may seize property listed under § 13-201 of this subtitle as an incident to an arrest or search and seizure.

An officer who seizes property under this section shall place the property under seal or remove the property to a location designated by the Department of State Police or by the law enforcement unit having jurisdiction in the locality.

paragraph.text: By an appropriate inquiry and investigation, the seizing authority shall attempt to identify and locate the owner of a handgun that is seized.
If the owner is a resident of the State, the seizing authority may return the handgun to the owner.

If the owner of the handgun is not a resident of the State, the seizing authority shall send the handgun for disposition to the appropriate law enforcement unit where the owner is a resident if the handgun:

subparagraph.text: is not needed for investigation or evidence; or
is not disposed of under subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: If the seizing authority under subsection (a) of this section does not return the handgun to its owner, the seizing authority shall promptly notify the owner that the owner may apply within 30 days to the seizing authority for a review to determine whether the owner knew or should have known that the handgun was worn, carried, transported, or used in violation of § 4-203 or § 4-204 of the Criminal Law Article, and whether the owner is qualified to possess the handgun.

Qualification for possession of a handgun is the same as for sale or transfer of a handgun under §§ 5-103, 5-104, 5-118, 5-119, 5-120, 5-121, 5-122, 5-123, 5-124, 5-125, 5-126, and 5-127 of the Public Safety Article.

subsection.text: A person who knowingly gives false information or makes a material misstatement in an application for review or an investigation relating to an application is subject to the penalties under § 5-139 of the Public Safety Article.

paragraph.text: On timely receipt of an application, the seizing authority shall hold an informal review to determine whether the owner knew or should have known of the use or intended use of a handgun that is seized in violation of § 4-203 or § 4-204 of the Criminal Law Article.
The review is not subject to the Administrative Procedure Act.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the handgun that is seized shall be released to the owner if the seizing authority decides in favor of the owner and the owner is qualified to possess the handgun.
If the handgun is needed as evidence in a criminal case or investigation, the handgun shall be promptly returned when the case or investigation ends.
After review, if the seizing authority determines that the handgun should be forfeited to the State, the owner shall be notified at the owner’s last known address.
Within 30 days after notification, the owner may ask the appropriate District Court for release of the handgun.
The State’s Attorney shall represent the State in the action.
The District Court shall hear the matter and grant proper relief in accordance with this subtitle.
In a proceeding in a criminal cause involving a seized handgun, a court may order forfeiture or release of the seized handgun in accordance with this subsection.

A person who has made a written claim of ownership of a handgun to the seizing authority or the State’s Attorney shall be notified of the proceeding and of the claimant’s right to present the claim at the proceeding.
A claimant who has completed the review procedure provided for by this subtitle is not entitled to a second review under this subsection.

subsection.text: If a timely application for a review or a complaint to the court under § 13-204 of this subtitle does not occur, and an order for release under subsection (a) of this section is not issued, the handgun shall be:

paragraph.text: forfeited to the State without further proceedings; and
destroyed by the seizing authority or disposed of in accordance with § 13-206 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an owner of a seized handgun is not identified and located, the handgun is forfeited to the State without further proceedings.
Whenever property is forfeited under this subtitle, the law enforcement unit that sought forfeiture of the property may only:

paragraph.text: order the property retained for the official use of the law enforcement unit;
destroy the forfeited property; or
sell, exchange, or transfer the forfeited property to another law enforcement unit for official use by that unit.

subsection.text: Within 30 days after disposing of forfeited property, a law enforcement unit shall send to the Secretary of State Police:

paragraph.text: a description of the property forfeited;
the type of disposition made; and
the identity of the person to whom the property was transferred for disposal, retention, or official use.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a vehicle unless the owner authorized or allowed the vehicle to be used or employed in concealing, conveying, or transporting explosives during the course of a violation of Title 11, Subtitle 1 of the Public Safety Article.

In addition to any other penalty provided for a violation of Title 11, Subtitle 1 of the Public Safety Article, if a person on whom a penalty is imposed under § 11-116 of the Public Safety Article uses or employs a motor vehicle, other vehicle, vessel, or aircraft in concealing, conveying, or transporting explosives during the course of a violation of Title 11, Subtitle 1 of the Public Safety Article, the court on conviction of the person shall order the motor vehicle, other vehicle, vessel, or aircraft to be forfeited to the State or a county, based on which jurisdiction initiated the investigation.

If a court orders forfeiture under subsection (b) of this section, the interest transferred to the State or county is subordinate to the holder of a perfected security interest in the motor vehicle, other vehicle, vessel, or aircraft.

paragraph.text: After discharging any perfected security interest in a forfeited motor vehicle, other vehicle, vessel, or aircraft, the Secretary of State Police or the local governing body of a county may:

subparagraph.text: use the forfeited motor vehicle, other vehicle, vessel, or aircraft for public purposes; or
sell, exchange, or convey the forfeited motor vehicle, other vehicle, vessel, or aircraft.

paragraph.text: Any money received from the sale, exchange, or conveyance shall be deposited in the General Fund of the State or county.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Forfeiting authority” has the meaning stated in § 12–101 of this article.
“Governing body” has the meaning stated in § 12–101 of this article.
“Lienholder” has the meaning stated in § 12–101 of this article.
“Mortgage Fraud law” means the Maryland Mortgage Fraud Protection Act, Title 7, Subtitle 4 of the Real Property Article.
“Owner” has the meaning stated in § 12–101 of this article.
“Proceeds” includes property derived directly or indirectly in connection with or as a result of a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.

paragraph.text: “Property” includes:

subparagraph.text: real property and anything growing on or attached to real property;
personal property; and
money.

paragraph.text: “Property” does not include a lessor’s interest in property subject to a bona fide lease, unless the forfeiting authority can show that:

subparagraph.text: the lessor participated in a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law; or
the property was the proceeds of a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.

subsection.text: “Seizing authority” has the meaning stated in § 12–101 of this article.

section.text: The following property is subject to forfeiture:

paragraph.text: property used or intended for use in the course of a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law;
property derived from or realized through a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law; and
proceeds of property described in item (1) or (2) of this section.

subsection.text: Property or an interest in property may not be forfeited if the owner establishes by a preponderance of the evidence that the violation of the Mortgage Fraud law was committed without the owner’s actual knowledge.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, property used as the principal family residence may not be forfeited under this subtitle unless one of the owners of the property was convicted of a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.
Without a conviction, a court may order a forfeiture of property used as the principal family residence if the owner of the family residence:

subparagraph.text: fails to appear for a required court appearance; and
fails to surrender to the jurisdiction of the court within 180 days after the required court appearance.

subsection.text: Property used as the principal family residence by a husband and wife and held by the husband and wife as tenants by the entirety may not be forfeited unless:

paragraph.text: the property was used in connection with:

subparagraph.text: a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law; or
an attempt or conspiracy to violate the Mortgage Fraud law; and

paragraph.text: both the husband and wife are convicted of:

subparagraph.text: a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law; or
an attempt or conspiracy to violate the Mortgage Fraud law.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, property subject to forfeiture under this subtitle may be seized in accordance with the procedures set forth in §§ 12–202, 12–203, and 12–208 through 12–211 of this article.
The probable cause required under § 12–202(a)(2)(v) of this article is probable cause to believe that the property has been used or is intended to be used in violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, forfeiture of property under this subtitle shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in §§ 12–301 through 12–308 of this article.
The allegation required under § 12–305(a)(7) of this article refers to the Mortgage Fraud law rather than the Controlled Dangerous Substances law.

Except as provided in subsections (e) and (f) of this section and § 12–403(c) of this article, an owner’s interest in real property may be forfeited if the real property was used in connection with a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.
Forfeiture proceedings for real property may be brought in the jurisdiction where:

paragraph.text: the criminal charges are pending;
the owner resides; or
the real property is located.

If forfeiture proceedings for real property are brought in a jurisdiction other than where the real property is located, a notice of pending litigation shall be filed in the jurisdiction where the real property is located.
A notice of pending litigation required under this subsection shall include at least:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the owner of the real property;
a description of the real property; and
a description of the reasons for the filing of the forfeiture proceedings and notice of pending litigation.

subsection.text: If an owner of real property used as the principal family residence is convicted under the Mortgage Fraud law and the owner files an appeal of the conviction, the court shall stay forfeiture proceedings under § 12–403(c) of this article or subsection (f) of this section against the real property during the pendency of the appeal.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, there is a rebuttable presumption that property or part of a property in which a person has an ownership interest is subject to forfeiture as proceeds, if the State establishes by clear and convincing evidence that:

subparagraph.text: the person has violated the Mortgage Fraud law;
the property was acquired by the person during the violation or within a reasonable time after the violation; and
there was no other likely source for the property.

paragraph.text: A claimant of the property has the burden of proof to rebut the presumption established under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Real property used as the principal family residence may not be forfeited under subsection (e) of this section unless:

paragraph.text: an owner of the real property was convicted under subsection (e)(1) of this section; or
the real property is covered by § 13–403(b)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this section, disposition of property after forfeiture under this subtitle shall be subject to §§ 12–401, 12–402, and 12–404 of this article.

The court determination under § 12–402(c) of this article shall include that the property was being used or was to be used in violation of the Mortgage Fraud law rather than the Controlled Dangerous Substances law.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Identifiable losses” include:

sub-subparagraph.text: expenses necessary to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: discover the extent of a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law;
repair damages resulting from a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law, including repairing credit ratings and correcting errors in consumer reports; and
prevent further damages resulting from a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law; and

sub-subparagraph.text: lost wages resulting from time away from work in order to rectify any fraud caused by a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.

subparagraph.text: “Victim” includes a business that loses any thing of value as a result of a violation of the Mortgage Fraud law.

paragraph.text: Disposition of forfeited property under this subtitle shall follow the procedures in this subsection.
Whenever property is forfeited under this subtitle, the governing body where the property was seized shall sell the property at public auction.
The proceeds of a sale under this subsection shall be distributed as follows:

subparagraph.text: first, to pay all proper expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture and sale, including expenses of seizure, maintenance of custody, advertising, and court costs;
second, for restitution as ordered by the court to victims to pay for identifiable losses resulting from the violation of the Mortgage Fraud law; and
finally, to the General Fund of the State.

section.text: Lienholders of property seized under this subtitle shall have the rights and obligations set forth in Title 12, Subtitle 5 of this article.
In this title, “Commission” means the State Prosecutor Selection and Disabilities Commission.

paragraph.text: There is an Office of the State Prosecutor.
The Office of the State Prosecutor is an independent unit in the Office of the Attorney General.
An individual is eligible to be the State Prosecutor only if the individual:

subparagraph.text: executes an affidavit that the individual will not accept appointment to, or be a candidate for, a State or local office during the period of service as the State Prosecutor and for at least 3 years immediately after the individual last serves as the State Prosecutor; and
has lawfully and actively practiced law in the State for at least 5 years.

paragraph.text: The State Prosecutor shall renew the affidavit every 2 years during the period of service.
A failure to renew the affidavit under this subsection shall subject the State Prosecutor to removal from office under this section.
The State Prosecutor shall be:

subparagraph.text: nominated by the Commission; and
appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.text: The term of the State Prosecutor is 6 years.
At the end of a term, the State Prosecutor continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: Only on the recommendation of the Commission, the Governor may remove the State Prosecutor for:

paragraph.text: misconduct in office;
persistent failure to perform the duties of the office; or
conduct prejudicial to the proper administration of justice.

subsection.text: The State Prosecutor is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget, but not less than the salary of a judge of a circuit court.
There is a State Prosecutor Selection and Disabilities Commission.
The Commission consists of:

paragraph.text: the Attorney General; and
six individuals appointed by the Governor as follows:

subparagraph.text: two individuals shall be appointed from a list of two or more nominees submitted by the President of the Senate:

sub-subparagraph.text: only one of the individuals appointed shall be a lawyer; and
none of the nominees may be a member of the General Assembly or a full–time State employee;

subparagraph.text: two individuals shall be appointed from a list of two or more nominees submitted by the Speaker of the House of Delegates:

sub-subparagraph.text: only one of the individuals appointed shall be a lawyer; and
none of the nominees may be a member of the General Assembly or a full–time State employee;

subparagraph.text: one individual who:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall be appointed from a list of one or more nominees submitted by the Board of Governors of the Maryland State Bar Association; and
is a lawyer admitted to practice law in the State; and

subparagraph.text: one individual who:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall be appointed from a list of one or more nominees submitted by the governing board of the Maryland State’s Attorneys Association; and
is a State’s Attorney at the time of appointment and throughout the individual’s term on the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members of the Commission from the nominees submitted to the Governor under this section.
The Governor may reject an individual as a nominee only for cause.
If the Governor rejects an individual as a nominee, the Governor shall request the appropriate nominating authority to submit another nominee.
The term of an appointed member is 4 years.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required by the terms in effect for members on October 1, 2008.
An appointed member serves until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
An appointed member is eligible for reappointment.

subsection.text: From among the members, the Governor shall designate the chair of the Commission for the period that the Governor determines.
A vacancy that occurs on the Commission shall be filled by the Governor in the same manner as provided for appointments in this section.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation for serving on the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: On notification by the Governor that a vacancy exists or is about to occur in the position of State Prosecutor, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: seek and review applications of proposed nominees;
notify and request recommendations from the Maryland State Bar Association; and
seek recommendations from members of the Commission and interested citizens and groups.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: interview and evaluate each eligible applicant; and
nominate to the Governor, on a vote taken by secret ballot, one or more individuals whom a majority of the authorized membership of the Commission finds to be legally and professionally qualified.

subsection.text: The Commission shall report, in writing, to the Governor the name of the individual or individuals it nominates within 70 days after notification that a vacancy exists or is about to occur.

subparagraph.text: The Governor may reject a nominee for cause.
If a nominee is rejected for cause, the Commission shall submit another nominee.

paragraph.text: If the Governor rejects a nominee:

subparagraph.text: the Governor shall send to the Commission a written statement that contains the reasons for the rejection; and
a copy of the statement of rejection shall be furnished to the nominee.

paragraph.text: The statement shall be confidential and privileged, unless the privilege is deemed waived by the Commission by the acts of the nominee in presenting to the public the reason for the rejection.
The Commission may make the statement public.

subsection.text: The Governor shall exercise the power of appointment or rejection within 30 days after receipt of the Commission’s report.
The Commission may reprimand or recommend to the Governor the removal of the State Prosecutor if, after a hearing, the Commission finds that the State Prosecutor is guilty of:

paragraph.text: misconduct in office;
persistent failure to perform the duties of the office; or
conduct prejudicial to the proper administration of justice.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the proceedings, testimony, and other evidence before the Commission are confidential and privileged.
On taking final action, the Commission may make its order and the proceedings, testimony, and other evidence public.
On complaint or on its own initiative, the Commission may investigate allegations against the State Prosecutor that may warrant removal or reprimand.
The Commission may:

subparagraph.text: conduct hearings;
administer oaths and affirmations;
issue process to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of evidence; and
require a person to testify and produce evidence by granting the person immunity from prosecution, penalty, or forfeiture.

section.text: The State Prosecutor has the powers and duties established under §§ 14–107 through 14–111 of this title.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the State Prosecutor may investigate:

subparagraph.text: a criminal offense under the State election laws;
a criminal offense under the State Public Ethics Law;

a violation of the State bribery laws in which an official or employee of the State, a political subdivision of the State, or a bicounty or multicounty unit of the State was the offeror, offeree, or intended offeror or offeree of a bribe;

an offense constituting criminal malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance in office committed by an officer or employee of the State, of a political subdivision of the State, or of a bicounty or multicounty unit of the State; and
a violation of the State extortion, perjury, or obstruction of justice laws related to an activity described in this paragraph.

paragraph.text: The State Prosecutor may not investigate an offense alleged to have been committed by the State Prosecutor or a member of the State Prosecutor’s staff.
The State Prosecutor may investigate an alleged offense under paragraph (1) of this subsection on the State Prosecutor’s own initiative or on request of:

subparagraph.text: the Governor;
the Attorney General;
the General Assembly;
the State Ethics Commission; or
a State’s Attorney.

paragraph.text: An individual who is advised by the State Prosecutor that the individual is under investigation under paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection may release this information to the public, as well as any results of the investigation that pertain to the individual.

subsection.text: On request of the Governor, the Attorney General, the General Assembly, or a State’s Attorney, the State Prosecutor may investigate criminal activity that is committed:

paragraph.text: partly in the State and partly in another jurisdiction; or
in more than one political subdivision of the State.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the State Prosecutor finds that an alleged violation of the criminal law set forth in § 14–107 of this title has occurred, the State Prosecutor shall make a confidential report of the findings and any recommendations for prosecution to the Attorney General and the State’s Attorney for the county in which jurisdiction exists to prosecute the matter.
A report of the findings and recommendations regarding allegations of offenses committed by a State’s Attorney need not be made to that State’s Attorney.

If the State Prosecutor finds that there has not been a violation of criminal law or the State Prosecutor does not recommend prosecution, the State Prosecutor shall report the findings to the person who requested the investigation.
If the General Assembly requested the investigation, the report shall be made to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Delegates.
On request of the person who was the subject of the investigation, the report shall be made available to the public as soon as possible.

The State Prosecutor may prosecute a criminal offense set forth in the State Prosecutor’s report of the findings and recommendations if, within 45 days after receipt of the report, the State’s Attorney fails to file charges and begin prosecution in accordance with the recommendations.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the State Prosecutor may immediately prosecute a criminal offense that is set forth in the State Prosecutor’s report and that is alleged to have been committed by the State’s Attorney.
The State Prosecutor shall represent the State in each appeal and postconviction proceeding that arises from a prosecution that the State Prosecutor conducts.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Attorney General may represent the State or assist the State Prosecutor:

subparagraph.text: on the request of the State Prosecutor; or
as required by law in an appeal or collateral proceeding described in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The State Prosecutor has all the powers and duties of a State’s Attorney, including the use of a grand jury in any county, when the State Prosecutor:

paragraph.text: investigates a case under § 14–107 of this title; or
prosecutes a case under § 14–109 of this title.

For the limited purpose of furthering an ongoing criminal investigation under § 14–107 of this title, the State Prosecutor may issue a subpoena to a person to produce telephone, business, governmental, or corporate records or documents.
The subpoena may be served in the same manner as one issued by a circuit court.
A person may have an attorney present during any contact with the State Prosecutor made under subsection (b) of this section.
The State Prosecutor shall advise a person of the right to counsel when the subpoena is served.

subparagraph.text: The State Prosecutor immediately may report the failure of a person to obey a lawfully served subpoena under subsection (b) of this section to the circuit court of the county having jurisdiction.
The State Prosecutor shall provide a copy of the subpoena and proof of service to the circuit court.

paragraph.text: After conducting a hearing at which the person who allegedly failed to comply with a subpoena issued under subsection (b) of this section has an opportunity to be heard and represented by counsel, the court may grant appropriate relief.

subsection.text: This section does not allow the contravention, denial, or abrogation of a privilege or right recognized by law.

section.text: The trial of a case that the State Prosecutor prosecutes in accordance with § 14–109 of this title shall take place before the court having jurisdiction in the county in which the offense was entirely or partly committed, subject to removal in accordance with the Maryland Rules.

subsection.text: The budget of the State Prosecutor and the Office of the State Prosecutor shall be a part of the budget of the Office of the Attorney General.
The State Prosecutor may appoint and employ the professional, investigative, and clerical staff provided in the State budget.
The State Prosecutor and the staff attorneys appointed by the State Prosecutor shall devote full time to their official duties and may not engage in the private practice of law.

paragraph.text: To the extent practicable, the State Prosecutor shall use the services and personnel of:

subparagraph.text: the Office of the Attorney General;
the Department of State Police; and
other State and law enforcement units.

paragraph.text: The units listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall cooperate, to the extent feasible, with the State Prosecutor and the State Prosecutor’s staff.

section.text: The State Prosecutor shall meet and confer regularly with the Attorney General and the State’s Attorneys.
The State Prosecutor shall submit an annual report on activities of the Office of the State Prosecutor that are not confidential to:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the Attorney General; and
subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Coordinator” means the State’s Attorneys’ Coordinator.
“Council” means the State’s Attorneys’ Coordination Council.
“State’s Attorney” means the individual holding that office under Article V, § 7 of the Maryland Constitution.

section.text: Subject to Title 14 of this article, a State’s Attorney shall, in the county served by the State’s Attorney, prosecute and defend on the part of the State all cases in which the State may be interested.

subsection.text: Each State’s Attorney shall annually provide a corporate surety bond payable to the State in the amount of $5,000.
The bond shall be conditioned on the State’s Attorney faithfully:

paragraph.text: performing the duties of the office; and
accounting for funds and property received under color of the office.
The bond shall be deposited with the Comptroller.
Premiums on the bond shall be an expense of the office of the State’s Attorney.

section.text: A State’s Attorney shall prepare and submit to the Division of Parole and Probation and the Division of Correction a summary of the facts and evidence in each case tried in the circuit court for the county served by the State’s Attorney in which:

paragraph.text: the defendant was sentenced to imprisonment for 18 months or more; and
the Division of Parole and Probation did not prepare a presentence investigation report.

For the limited purpose of furthering an ongoing criminal investigation, a State’s Attorney or a deputy State’s Attorney designated in writing by the State’s Attorney may issue in the county served by the State’s Attorney a subpoena to a person to produce telephone, business, governmental, or corporate records or documents.
The subpoena may be served in the same manner as one issued by a circuit court.
A person may have an attorney present during any contact made under subsection (a) of this section with a State’s Attorney or an agent of the State’s Attorney.
The State’s Attorney shall advise a person of the right to counsel when the subpoena is served.

subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney immediately may report the failure of a person to obey a lawfully served subpoena under subsection (a) of this section to the circuit court of the county served by the State’s Attorney.
The State’s Attorney shall provide a copy of the subpoena and proof of service to the circuit court.

paragraph.text: After conducting a hearing at which the person who allegedly failed to comply with a subpoena issued under subsection (a) of this section has an opportunity to be heard and represented by counsel, the court may grant appropriate relief.

subsection.text: This section does not allow the contravention, denial, or abrogation of a privilege or right recognized by law.

If necessary due to an absence, sickness, resignation, or death of a State’s Attorney, the circuit court for the county may appoint a competent individual to perform the duties of the State’s Attorney in conducting criminal or civil cases arising or pending in the circuit court until:

paragraph.text: the State’s Attorney is able to attend and act in person; or
a new State’s Attorney is appointed and qualified.

subsection.text: An individual appointed under subsection (a) of this section shall receive the same compensation as the State’s Attorney who is replaced.

section.text: There is a State’s Attorneys’ Coordination Council.

subsection.text: The Council consists of:

paragraph.text: the Attorney General;
the State’s Attorney for Anne Arundel County;
the State’s Attorney for Baltimore City;
the State’s Attorney for Baltimore County;
the State’s Attorney for Montgomery County;
the State’s Attorney for Prince George’s County;
the State’s Attorney for Allegany County, Frederick County, Garrett County, or Washington County who is chosen by a majority vote of the State’s Attorneys for those counties;
the State’s Attorney for Calvert County, Charles County, or St. Mary’s County who is chosen by a majority vote of the State’s Attorneys for those counties;
the State’s Attorney for Caroline County, Cecil County, Kent County, Queen Anne’s County, or Talbot County who is chosen by a majority vote of the State’s Attorneys for those counties;
the State’s Attorney for Carroll County, Harford County, or Howard County who is chosen by a majority vote of the State’s Attorneys for those counties; and
the State’s Attorney for Dorchester County, Somerset County, Wicomico County, or Worcester County who is chosen by a majority vote of the State’s Attorneys for those counties.
This subsection only applies to members chosen in accordance with subsection (a)(7) through (11) of this section.
The term of a member of the Council is 2 years.
A member continues to serve until a successor is chosen and qualifies.
A member may serve only during the time the member holds the office that qualifies the member for membership.
A member is eligible to serve more than one term.
A vacancy on the Council shall be filled in the same manner used to choose the original membership in subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: Membership on the Council does not constitute holding an office of profit.

section.text: The Council shall designate from among its members a chair and vice chair who:

paragraph.text: shall serve for a term of 2 years; and
are eligible for reelection.

subsection.text: A majority of the members of the Council is a quorum.

paragraph.text: The Council shall meet at least four times each year.
The Council shall hold special meetings when called by:

subparagraph.text: the chair, on the chair’s own initiative or on the written request of three Council members; or
the vice chair, in the absence of the chair.

paragraph.text: The Council shall establish procedures and requirements with respect to meetings, deliberations, and the administration of the functions of the Council.

subsection.text: The Coordinator shall serve as the secretary to the Council and perform the duties and responsibilities the Council directs in order to carry out the functions of the Council.

section.text: After consultation with the State Board of Victim Services, the Council shall adopt regulations for the administration of the Victim and Witness Protection and Relocation Program established under § 11–902 of this article.

paragraph.text: There is an office of State’s Attorneys’ Coordinator.
The Coordinator shall be appointed by and serve atthe pleasure of the Council.

subsection.text: An individual is eligible to be the Coordinator if, at the time of appointment, the individual is admitted to practice law in the State.
The Coordinator shall receive the salary provided in the State budget.
The Coordinator shall devote full time to the Coordinator’s official duties and may not engage in the private practice of law.
The Coordinator may appoint and employ the professional and clerical staff approved by the Council and as provided in the State budget.
The Council shall prepare and submit to the Governor a budget for the office each fiscal year.
Each unit of State and local government shall cooperate to the extent practicable with the Coordinator and the staff of the Coordinator in the discharge of the Coordinator’s duties.

section.text: The Coordinator shall:

paragraph.text: establish and implement standard and specialized training programs for and provide materials to State’s Attorneys and professional staffs of State’s Attorneys;
provide and coordinate continuing legal education programs and services for State’s Attorneys and professional staffs of State’s Attorneys, including:

subparagraph.text: legal research;
technical assistance;
technical and professional publications; and

the compiling and disseminating of information concerning and the advising of State’s Attorneys about developments in the criminal law and the administration of criminal justice relating to the duties of the office of State’s Attorney;

paragraph.text: with the approval of the Council, establish and implement uniform reporting procedures for State’s Attorneys and professional staffs of State’s Attorneys to maintain and provide statistical data and information relating to prosecutorial functions and standards of the office of State’s Attorney;
with the approval of the Council, accept and expend funds, grants, and gifts and accept services from public or private sources;
with the approval of the Council, enter into agreements and contracts with public or private agencies or educational institutions;
provide services and functions as the Council directs to carry out the duties of the office of Coordinator;
administer the Victim and Witness Protection and Relocation Program established under § 11–902 of this article, including consideration of and approving the release of moneys from the Program;
consult with the State Board of Victim Services on the administration of the Victim and Witness Protection and Relocation Program; and
meet and confer regularly with the Attorney General, the State’s Attorneys, and the Council.
The State’s Attorney for a county shall receive:

subparagraph.text: an annual salary for performing the duties of the office as set forth in the public general laws and the public local laws of the county; and
an annual payment for office, travel, and other expenses as provided by law and the current practice of the county.

paragraph.text: Unless otherwise specified, a county shall pay the salary and expenses in equal monthly installments.
Except for necessary travel and other expenses incurred in trying a case removed to another county, a State’s Attorney may not receive any other compensation for performing the duties of the office.
Any fees to which the State’s Attorney may be entitled shall be:

subparagraph.text: collected and paid to the governing body of the county; and
credited to the general fund of the county.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Allegany County.

The State’s Attorney’s salary is 90% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland in effect on December 31 of the year immediately before the start of the State’s Attorney’s term of office.
As determined by the State’s Attorney, the State’s Attorney, a deputy State’s Attorney, or an assistant State’s Attorney shall:

paragraph.text: present cases to the grand jury; and
perform other necessary duties in relation to the grand jury, the District Court of Maryland, and the circuit court, including the juvenile court.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint:

paragraph.text: two deputy State’s Attorneys who shall serve full time and whose salaries may not be less than 80% of the salary of the State’s Attorney; and
as many assistant State’s Attorneys that the county commissioners authorize and fund.
The State’s Attorney shall appoint a county investigator and an assistant county investigator in accordance with §§ 12–1A and 12–1B of the Allegany County Code.
The county investigator and assistant county investigator shall be funded in accordance with § 12–1A of the Allegany County Code.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Anne Arundel County.
The State’s Attorney’s salary:

paragraph.text: for calendar year 2003, is equal to the salary of a circuit court judge as of December 31, 2002; and
shall be increased each calendar year thereafter by 3% over the salary of the State’s Attorney for the previous calendar year.
The State’s Attorney may:

sub-subparagraph.text: appoint two deputy State’s Attorneys; and
subject to the approval of the county, set salaries for the deputy State’s Attorneys that may not exceed 90% of the State’s Attorney’s salary; and
appoint the number of assistant State’s Attorneys as provided by the county; and
subject to approval by the county, set salaries for the assistant State’s Attorneys that may not exceed 80% of the State’s Attorney’s salary.

paragraph.text: Subject to approval by the administrative judge of the circuit court, the State’s Attorney may:

subparagraph.text: appoint a temporary assistant State’s Attorney for a particular case or series of cases; and
subject to the approval of the county, set the compensation for the temporary assistant State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint clerical, administrative, investigative, and other staff the State’s Attorney considers necessary for the proper conduct of the office.

subparagraph.text: Except in connection with performing the duties of the office, the State’s Attorney may not appear as counsel or represent any party before a court or unit of the State or a political subdivision of the State.
The State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.

paragraph.text: The deputy State’s Attorneys shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of criminal law.
Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: may not engage in the private practice of criminal law; and
except for one assistant State’s Attorney, shall serve full time.

paragraph.text: In accordance with the Anne Arundel County Code, the State’s Attorney may designate two or more assistant State’s Attorneys to share one or more full–time positions.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Baltimore County.

paragraph.text: Subject to Article III, § 35 of the Maryland Constitution and paragraph (2) of this subsection, beginning with the term of the State’s Attorney who was elected to that position in 1982, the State’s Attorney’s salary:

subparagraph.text: is equal to the salary of a circuit court judge; and
shall be increased 5% each year during the State’s Attorney’s term of office.
Beginning with the term of the State’s Attorney elected to that position in 2010, the salary of the State’s Attorney is $194,276; and
for the year beginning on January 1, 2012, and each year thereafter until January 1, 2023, the salary shall be increased by 1%.

The State’s Attorney shall appoint two deputy State’s Attorneys, one of whom shall be designated deputy State’s Attorney of trial and administration and the other shall be designated deputy State’s Attorney of operations.
A deputy State’s Attorney shall perform the work that the State’s Attorney requires.
Subject to the approval of the County Executive and the County Council, the State’s Attorney shall set the salaries of the deputy State’s Attorneys.
As authorized by the County Executive, the State’s Attorney may appoint assistant State’s Attorneys.
Subject to the approval of the County Executive and the County Council, the State’s Attorney shall set the salaries of the assistant State’s Attorneys.

paragraph.text: The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to represent the State before the grand jury and in criminal proceedings.
The State’s Attorney may appoint clerical, administrative, and other staff that the State’s Attorney considers necessary for the proper conduct of the office.
The staff appointed under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall perform clerical and other work as directed by the State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney and the deputy State’s Attorneys shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Calvert County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 90% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.
A salary increase shall take effect at the beginning of the elected term of office and may not increase during the term of office.
Subject to approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney shall appoint a deputy State’s Attorney and an assistant State’s Attorney, as needed.
The county commissioners shall set the salaries of the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
shall perform work as directed by the State’s Attorney; and
may present cases to the grand jury, sign indictments and criminal informations, and perform other functions necessary to the operation of the Office.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Caroline County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 80% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.
The State’s Attorney is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Carroll County.

subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 80% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.
A salary increase shall take effect at the beginning of the elected term of office and may not increase during the term of office.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: provide space for the offices of the State’s Attorney and pay the expenses of the office, including general operating expenses, equipment costs, and reasonable costs for secretarial or stenographic needs; or
as determined by the county commissioners, pay a reasonable allowance to reimburse the State’s Attorney for the costs of the operation of the office.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney:

subparagraph.text: may appoint two deputy State’s Attorneys and the number of assistant State’s Attorneys necessary to staff the office; and
subject to the approval of the county commissioners, shall set the salaries for the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys.

In addition to the assistant State’s Attorneys appointed under paragraph (1) of this subsection, if both the State’s Attorney and the resident judge of the circuit court of the county consider it necessary and the judge approves, the State’s Attorney may appoint an assistant State’s Attorney.
The county commissioners shall set the salary of an assistant State’s Attorney appointed under this paragraph.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time.
This section applies only in Cecil County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: a salary that is 95% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland; and
the same benefits as a full–time county employee.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney:

subparagraph.text: is entitled to a reasonable expense allowance for the operation of the office and performance of the duties of State’s Attorney as provided in the county budget; and
