subject to the approval of the administrative judge of the circuit court for the county, may spend $1,500 each year for special work and employing extra help.
The State’s Attorney may appoint one deputy State’s Attorney and the number of assistant State’s Attorneys as provided in the county budget.
The salary of the deputy State’s Attorney and the assistant State’s Attorneys shall be as provided in the county budget.

paragraph.text: The deputy State’s Attorney and the assistant State’s Attorneys have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to represent the State before the grand jury and in criminal proceedings.
The deputy State’s Attorney and the assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
serve part time; and
are entitled to the same benefits as a full–time county employee.
The State’s Attorney may appoint clerical, secretarial, administrative, investigative, and other support staff that the State’s Attorney considers necessary for the proper conduct of the office.
The State’s Attorney’s executive secretary and criminal investigators serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney.

Except for the State’s Attorney’s executive secretary and criminal investigators, the positions appointed under this subsection are subject to county personnel policies and procedures governing county employees.

paragraph.text: The salaries of the positions appointed under this subsection shall be as provided in the county budget.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Charles County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is equal to the salary of a circuit court judge.
Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney is entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred during the performance of the duties of the office.
The State’s Attorney may appoint deputy State’s Attorneys and assistant State’s Attorneys.
Subject to the approval of the county commissioners and paragraph (3) of this subsection, the State’s Attorney shall set the salary for positions appointed under this subsection.
The salary of an assistant State’s Attorney may not exceed the salary of the State’s Attorney.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
shall perform work as directed by the State’s Attorney or as authorized by law; and
may present cases to the grand jury, sign indictments and criminal informations, and perform other functions necessary to operate the office.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint clerical, administrative, investigative, and other staff that the State’s Attorney considers necessary for the proper conduct of the office.
Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney shall set the salaries for the employees appointed under this subsection.
An employee appointed under this subsection is entitled to the same benefits as a county employee.
The State’s Attorney:

subparagraph.text: shall serve full time; and
except in connection with performing the duties of the office, may not:

sub-subparagraph.text: appear as counsel or represent any party before a court or unit of the State or a political subdivision of the State; or
otherwise engage in the private practice of law.

paragraph.text: A deputy State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
An assistant State’s Attorney may serve full time or part time and may not engage in the private practice of criminal law.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Dorchester County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 80% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

Subject to the approval of the County Council, the State’s Attorney is entitled to an allowance for the expenses of operating the office, including the costs of telephone charges, office supplies and equipment, postage, travel, training, conferences, books and publications, and premiums on office bonds.
The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of full–time or part–time deputy State’s Attorneys and assistant State’s Attorneys that the County Council approves.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
receive compensation as approved by the County Council; and
have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to present cases to the grand jury and perform all other necessary duties in relation to the grand jury and the operation of the office.

subsection.text: Subject to the approval of the County Council, the State’s Attorney may employ administrative and clerical employees who shall:

paragraph.text: receive salaries in accordance with the county pay scale; and
be considered county employees and members of the pension system in which a county employee is eligible for membership.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney:

paragraph.text: shall serve full time;
may not engage in the private practice of law; and
except in connection with performing the duties of the office, may not appear professionally in a criminal proceeding in the State.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Frederick County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s annual salary is equal to the salary of a circuit court judge.
The county commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: provide an office in the courthouse for the State’s Attorney;
pay the office expenses, including general operating expenses and the cost of equipment; and
pay the reasonable salary of a stenographer to be appointed by the State’s Attorney.
The State’s Attorney may appoint two deputy State’s Attorneys who shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
under the direction of the State’s Attorney, present cases to the grand jury and perform other necessary duties in relation to the grand jury and the operation of the office.

subparagraph.text: Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney shall set the salary of each deputy State’s Attorney.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of full–time and part–time assistant State’s Attorneys that are approved by the county commissioners and who:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
receive the compensation that the county commissioners approve; and
have the same legal powers that the State’s Attorney has to present cases to the grand jury and perform other necessary duties in relation to the grand jury and the operation of the office.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney may appoint other staff.
Employees appointed under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
receive the compensation that the county commissioners approve.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney and deputy State’s Attorneys may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Garrett County.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall set the State’s Attorney’s salary in accordance with Chapter 91 of the Public Local Laws of Garrett County.

subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s allowance for office expenses shall be at least $10,000.
An allowance of more than $10,000 shall be at the discretion of the county commissioners.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the county commissioners and as provided for in the county budget, the State’s Attorney may appoint assistant State’s Attorneys.
An assistant State’s Attorney shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
receive a salary of at least $25,000.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the county commissioners and if provided for in the county budget, the State’s Attorney may appoint investigators who shall:

subparagraph.text: be law enforcement officers in the State; and
have the same powers, rights, protections, and benefits as a county deputy sheriff.
The State’s Attorney may employ clerical, administrative, investigative, and other staff necessary for the proper conduct of the office.

Subject to the approval of the county commissioners and in conformity with the county pay and classification plans, the State’s Attorney shall set the salaries and classifications for the employees described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time.
This section applies only in Harford County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is $98,500.

Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, on or after July 1 of each year, the salary shall be adjusted using the annual Consumer Price Index that is published by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics:

subparagraph.text: for the period ending each December;
for all regions; and
to reflect the annual change in the “Consumer Price Index” for “All urban consumers” for the expenditure category “All items not seasonally adjusted”.

paragraph.text: The annual adjustment under paragraph (2) of this subsection may not exceed 3% in a fiscal year.
The county government shall pay all reasonable expenses for the conduct of the office.
The State’s Attorney may appoint:

subparagraph.text: not more than two deputy State’s Attorneys; and
the number of assistant State’s Attorneys authorized by the County Executive and County Council.

paragraph.text: The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
receive compensation as provided by the County Executive and County Council; and
have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to represent the State before the grand jury and in criminal proceedings.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint a secretary or clerical assistant who shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
receive a salary that conforms to the exempt classification and pay plan authorized by the County Executive and County Council.
The State’s Attorney may employ clerical, administrative, investigative, and other staff necessary for the proper conduct of the office.

Subject to the approval of the County Executive and County Council and in conformity with the county pay and classification plans, the State’s Attorney shall set salaries and classifications for employees appointed under this paragraph.
An employee appointed under this paragraph is entitled to the same benefits as a similarly classified county employee.

subsection.text: Except in connection with performing the duties of the office, the State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law or appear as counsel or represent any party before a court or unit of the State or a political subdivision of the State.
This section applies only in Howard County.
The State’s Attorney’s salary is equal to the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint two deputy State’s Attorneys and the number of assistant State’s Attorneys authorized by the County Executive.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, shall receive a salary set by the County Executive with the approval of the County Council;
shall have the same legal power as the State’s Attorney to represent the State before the grand jury and in criminal proceedings; and

under the direction of the State’s Attorney, may present cases to the grand jury, sign indictments and criminal informations, and perform other necessary duties relating to the grand jury and the operation of the office as directed by the State’s Attorney or authorized by law.

paragraph.text: The salary for a deputy State’s Attorney may not be less than $6,000 each year.
The State’s Attorney may employ an administrative assistant who may:

subparagraph.text: collect and distribute moneys payable for the support of dependents under orders issued from courts in this State or another state; and
retain 2% of the moneys collected to be paid to the County Council to defray the costs of the service.

paragraph.text: The salary of the administrative assistant shall be set by the County Executive with the approval of the County Council.

Not later than 3 months after the close of each fiscal year, the County Auditor shall examine the books and accounts of the State’s Attorney’s office and prepare a financial audit for the preceding fiscal year.
The financial audit shall be:

subparagraph.text: submitted to the County Executive and County Council; and
included in the annual audit of the county required by Article 19, § 40 of the Code.

paragraph.text: At any time the County Executive or County Council may order a special audit of the State’s Attorney’s office in accordance with § 213 of the Howard County Charter.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Kent County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 80% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

subparagraph.text: The county commissioners shall set the State’s Attorney’s allowance for office expenses.
The State’s Attorney shall submit expense vouchers to the county commissioners for approval and payment.
The State’s Attorney has a special fund allowance of $4,000 for the costs of investigations.
At the end of each fiscal year:

sub-subparagraph.text: the State’s Attorney shall account to the county commissioners for expenditures from the fund; and
any balance remaining in the fund shall revert to the general fund of the county.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may employ one or more deputy State’s Attorneys and assistant State’s Attorneys who shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
be members in good standing of the local bar.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall set the salaries of the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys.
The State’s Attorney may employ a criminal investigator who serves at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney.
The State’s Attorney may employ an administrative coordinator and other administrative and clerical staff that the State’s Attorney considers necessary for the conduct of the office.
The county commissioners shall set the salaries of the criminal investigator, administrative coordinator, and administrative and clerical staff.
The State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, a deputy or assistant State’s Attorney may engage in the private practice of law.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: The County Council shall set the salary of the State’s Attorney.
Subject to approval by the County Council, the State’s Attorney is entitled a reasonable expense allowance for the operation of the office and performance of the duties of the State’s Attorney.
The State’s Attorney may appoint two deputy State’s Attorneys and the number of assistant State’s Attorneys that the County Council approves.
Each deputy and assistant State’s Attorney is:

subparagraph.text: subject to the exclusive control of the State’s Attorney; and
entitled to the same benefits as a county employee under the merit system.

paragraph.text: The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: shall perform the work directed by the State’s Attorney or authorized by law; and

under the direction of the State’s Attorney, may present cases to the grand jury, sign indictments and criminal informations, and perform other necessary duties relating to the grand jury and the operation of the office.

In addition to the assistant State’s Attorneys appointed in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection, the State’s Attorney may file a petition in circuit court for authority to appoint additional assistant State’s Attorneys.
The State’s Attorney shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: include the reasons for the appointment in the petition; and
deliver notice of the petition to the County Executive and County Council.

subparagraph.text: The County Executive and County Council may file a response to each petition.
The county shall pay the salary and expenses of an assistant State’s Attorney appointed under this paragraph.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of special investigators approved by the County Council.

subparagraph.text: In addition to the special investigators appointed in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection, the State’s Attorney may file a petition in circuit court for authority to appoint additional special investigators.
The State’s Attorney shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: include the reasons for the appointment in the petition; and
deliver notice of the petition to the County Executive and County Council.

subparagraph.text: The County Executive and County Council may file a response to each petition.

paragraph.text: The county shall pay the salary and expenses of a special investigator appointed under this subsection.
A special investigator appointed under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is directly under the supervision of the State’s Attorney; and
shall perform each duty designated by the State’s Attorney.

paragraph.text: A special investigator appointed under this subsection is:

subparagraph.text: subject to the exclusive control of the State’s Attorney; and
entitled to the same benefits as a county employee under the merit system.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of administrative assistants, clerks, administrative aides, paralegal interns, and other staff that the County Council approves.
The employees appointed under this subsection are:

subparagraph.text: subject to the exclusive control of the State’s Attorney; and
entitled to the same benefits as county employees under the merit system.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney, deputy State’s Attorneys, and assistant State’s Attorneys shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
A special investigator shall serve full time and may not engage in other employment.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is $150,000.
The State’s Attorney’s salary and expenses shall be paid in equal semimonthly installments.
The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of deputy State’s Attorneys and assistant State’s Attorneys as authorized by law by the County Executive and County Council.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney.
The salary of a deputy State’s Attorney shall be within the discretion of the State’s Attorney but may not exceed a maximum salary authorized by law by the County Executive and County Council.
The salary of an assistant State’s Attorney shall be within the discretion of the State’s Attorney but may not exceed a maximum salary authorized by law by the County Executive and County Council.
The county shall pay the salaries of the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys in equal semimonthly installments.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys:

subparagraph.text: shall perform the work directed by the State’s Attorney or as authorized by law; and

under the direction of the State’s Attorney, may present cases to the grand jury, sign indictments and criminal informations, and perform other necessary duties relating to the grand jury and the operation of the office.
The State’s Attorney may appoint an administrative assistant who serves at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney.
The salary of the administrative assistant shall be within the discretion of the State’s Attorney but may not exceed a maximum salary authorized by law by the County Executive and County Council.
The administrative assistant is not subject to the regulations of the county merit system but is entitled to the same benefits as a county employee under the merit system.
Each eligible, full–time, nonexempt employee, as described in the Prince George’s County Labor Code, of the State’s Attorney’s office is subject to the Prince George’s County personnel law.
Employees described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: may organize and bargain collectively; and
are subject to the Prince George’s County Labor Code with regard to collective bargaining for compensation, including pension and fringe benefits, hours, and other terms and conditions of employment.

subparagraph.text: The County Executive is the employer of an employee described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph for the purpose of collective bargaining for hours and compensation, including pension and fringe benefits.

sub-subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney is the employer of an employee described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph for the purpose of collective bargaining for other terms and conditions of employment.
The funding required for a collective bargaining agreement negotiated by the State’s Attorney under this subparagraph is subject to the approval of the County Executive.

paragraph.text: Except in connection with duties of the office, the State’s Attorney or a deputy or assistant State’s Attorney may not appear as counsel or represent any party before a court or unit of the State, or political subdivision of the State.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the State’s Attorney or a deputy or assistant State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.
The State’s Attorney or a deputy or assistant State’s Attorney may participate in the pro bono program administered by the Prince George’s County Bar Foundation.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Queen Anne’s County.

subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is equal to the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.
The salary shall be set before the start of the elected term of office.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney is entitled to reasonable expenses as provided in the county budget for the operation of the office and the performance of the State’s Attorney’s duties.
Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney may appoint one or more deputy State’s Attorneys or assistant State’s Attorneys.
The county commissioners shall set the salary of each deputy and assistant State’s Attorney.

The State’s Attorney, deputy State’s Attorneys, or assistant State’s Attorneys shall present cases to the grand jury and perform other duties in relation to the grand jury, the circuit court, including the juvenile court, and the District Court that the State’s Attorney considers necessary.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not:

paragraph.text: engage in the private practice of law; or
except in connection with the duties of the office, appear professionally in a criminal proceeding in the State.

subsection.text: This section applies only in St. Mary’s County.

subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 90% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland and shall be paid biweekly.
A salary increase shall take effect at the beginning of the elected term of office and may not increase during the term of office.

The county commissioners shall provide for the administrative support staff, independent office facilities, office equipment, supplies, books, and other items necessary for the operation of the office.
The State’s Attorney shall present vouchers to the county commissioners for the payment of office expenses.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint one deputy State’s Attorney and two or more assistant State’s Attorneys who:

subparagraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
may be full–time or part–time employees.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney shall pay the salaries of the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys biweekly from money that the county commissioners appropriate each year.
The State’s Attorney may appoint:

subparagraph.text: administrative staff necessary for the operation of the office; and
one or more full–time or part–time investigators as employees.

paragraph.text: The staff appointed under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be in the county merit system.
The State’s Attorney shall pay the salaries of the investigators appointed under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection biweekly from money that the county commissioners appropriate each year.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not:

paragraph.text: engage in the private practice of law; and
except in connection with performing the duties of the office, appear professionally in a criminal proceeding in the State.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Somerset County.
The State’s Attorney’s salary is $98,000.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint a deputy State’s Attorney who shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and

present cases to the grand jury, sign indictments and criminal informations, and perform other functions necessary to the operation of the office and as directed by the State’s Attorney or as authorized by law.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall set a salary for the deputy State’s Attorney that may not exceed the salary of the State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may:

paragraph.text: appoint one or more assistants at salaries that the county commissioners set; and
hire one or more investigators at salaries provided in the county budget.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Talbot County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 80% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.
Subject to the approval of the County Council, the State’s Attorney is entitled to a reasonable allowance for the expenses of operating the office, including the costs of:

subparagraph.text: administrative, clerical, and secretarial expenses, including salaries and benefits;
telephone charges;
office supplies and equipment;
postage;
travel, training, and conferences;
books and publications; and
premiums on office bonds.
The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of full–time or part–time deputy State’s Attorneys and assistant State’s Attorneys that the County Council approves.
Each deputy and assistant State’s Attorney appointed under this paragraph shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
receive the compensation that the County Council approves; and
have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to present cases to the grand jury and perform necessary duties in relation to the grand jury and the operation of the office.

subparagraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint special assistant State’s Attorneys as the State’s Attorney considers necessary to serve in an investigation or a case.
A special assistant State’s Attorney appointed under this paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall serve on a temporary basis;
subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, shall receive compensation from the County Council in the form and amount authorized by order of the circuit court; and
may not be considered to hold an office for profit or to have vacated a public office or employment in another State’s Attorney’s office by serving as a special assistant State’s Attorney.

subparagraph.text: The county may not compensate an individual who is appointed as a special assistant State’s Attorney and is employed by the Office of the Attorney General, the Office of the State Prosecutor, or the Office of the State’s Attorney in another county.

Notwithstanding subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the county may enter into an agreement to reimburse the appropriate governmental unit for the services of an individual employed by that governmental unit who is appointed as a special assistant State’s Attorney under paragraph (2) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the County Council, the State’s Attorney may appoint full–time or part–time criminal investigators.

If the State’s Attorney appoints more than one criminal investigator, the State’s Attorney may designate one as chief investigator and assign other ranks and titles to the other criminal investigators.
A criminal investigator who is appointed under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney;
is subject to the regulations of the State’s Attorney;
shall perform the duties that the State’s Attorney designates;
shall take an oath of office that the clerk of the circuit court administers;
shall meet the criteria regarding training and experience that the State’s Attorney requires;
may serve a summons or subpoena that the State’s Attorney issues;
may wear or display appropriate metallic badges that the State’s Attorney authorizes; and
is not subject to Title 3, Subtitle 1 of the Public Safety Article.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may designate a criminal investigator as a peace officer if the criminal investigator meets the selection and training standards of the Police Training Commission as set forth in Title 3, Subtitle 2 of the Public Safety Article.
A criminal investigator designated as a peace officer may not be subject to Title 3, Subtitle 1 of the Public Safety Article.
In addition to the authority, duties, and limitations described under paragraph (3) of this subsection, a criminal investigator designated as a peace officer may:

subparagraph.text: arrest a person who commits a crime in the county or in a municipal corporation in the county;
serve a warrant, summons, or subpoena that the District Court of Maryland in the county or a circuit court issues; and
possess and carry a firearm, including a handgun, or other weapon that the State’s Attorney requires.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
An attorney appointed as a special assistant State’s Attorney under subsection (c)(2) of this section may not be precluded from the private practice of criminal law.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Washington County.
The State’s Attorney’s salary is 90% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney shall appoint:

subparagraph.text: at least one but not more than two deputy State’s Attorneys; and
as many assistant State’s Attorneys that are approved by the county commissioners and provided for in the county budget.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall set the salaries of the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney.
Under the direction of the State’s Attorney or in the State’s Attorney’s absence, the deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys shall have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to:

subparagraph.text: perform acts and duties in relation to all criminal proceedings; and
represent the State in all proceedings in relation to the grand jury, circuit court, District Court of Maryland, and units of the State or a political subdivision of the State.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Wicomico County.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney’s salary is 90% of the annual salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

After receiving a voucher submitted by the State’s Attorney, the County Council shall pay all expenses that the State’s Attorney considers necessary for the conduct of the office, including clerical and secretarial expenses, telephone charges, office supplies, postage, and premiums on official bonds.
The State’s Attorney shall maintain and staff an office in the Wicomico County courthouse.
Subject to the terms, conditions, and salaries as approved by the County Council, the State’s Attorney may appoint assistant State’s Attorneys who shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to represent the State before the grand jury and in criminal proceedings.

paragraph.text: In addition to the assistant State’s Attorneys appointed under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the State’s Attorney may appoint special assistant State’s Attorneys to serve for one or more cases:

subparagraph.text: with the prior approval of the resident judge of the circuit court and the County Council; and
subject to the terms, conditions, and salaries that the County Council approves.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
This section applies only in Worcester County.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the State’s Attorney’s salary is 90% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

By enacting an ordinance before the election filing deadline for the next term of office for the State’s Attorney, the county commissioners may set the salary at an amount exceeding 90% of the salary of a judge of the District Court of Maryland.

subparagraph.text: All other salaries, compensation, employee benefits, and expenses of the Office of the State’s Attorney are subject to the annual budget process and approval of the county commissioners in accordance with the budget and fiscal policies and purchasing laws of the county.
Processing the payroll of the Office of the State’s Attorney as part of the payroll of the county does not make employees of the Office of the State’s Attorney the employees of the county.

paragraph.text: The State’s Attorney may appoint the number of full–time or part–time deputy State’s Attorneys and assistant State’s Attorneys that the county commissioners approve.
The deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys appointed under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and

have the same legal powers as the State’s Attorney to present cases to the grand jury, represent the State in criminal proceedings, and perform necessary duties in relation to the grand jury and operation of the office that the State’s Attorney requires.

subsection.text: If authorized by an ordinance enacted by the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney may appoint special investigators who:

paragraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the State’s Attorney; and
shall perform work as directed by and under the supervision of the State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall serve full time and may not engage in the private practice of law.
On approval of the county commissioners, the State’s Attorney may hire the clerical, secretarial, and office employees that the State’s Attorney determines are needed.
All employees of the Office of the State’s Attorney, including deputy State’s Attorneys, assistant State’s Attorneys, investigators, clerical workers, secretaries, and office employees:

paragraph.text: are employees of the Office of the State’s Attorney and not of the county commissioners;
shall receive the same insurance, retirement, and leave benefits as county employees; and
are under the control of the State’s Attorney, subject to this section and the personnel rules and regulations that the county commissioners adopt by resolution for county employees.

subsection.text: The State’s Attorney shall perform the appointment, disciplinary, termination, and managerial functions for all employees of the Office of the State’s Attorney who are covered by the personnel rules and regulations that the county commissioners adopt.
The State’s Attorney may adopt office practices, manuals, rules of conduct, and other procedures to serve as conditions of employment for employees of the Office of the State’s Attorney.

paragraph.text: Except for members of the State Bar who serve as deputy or assistant State’s Attorneys, employees of the Office of the State’s Attorney may be disciplined or terminated for cause only in accordance with this section and the personnel rules and regulations that the county commissioners adopt.

When a new State’s Attorney takes office or at the beginning of a new term of a State’s Attorney, all clerical, secretarial, office, and other employees except for deputy and assistant State’s Attorneys shall remain in their positions and shall be considered rehired.

subsection.text: On request of the State’s Attorney, the county commissioners may provide in–kind support to the State’s Attorney for personnel matters.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board of Trustees” means the Board of Trustees of the Office of the Public Defender established under § 16–301 of this title.
“District” means an area conforming to the geographic boundaries of a District Court district established in § 1–602 of the Courts Article.
“Indigent individual” means an individual who qualifies as an indigent individual under § 16–210 of this title.

paragraph.text: “Office” means the Office of the Public Defender.
“Office” includes each district office and branch office of the Public Defender.

subsection.text: “Panel attorney” means an attorney who is eligible for appointment as an attorney for an indigent individual.
“Regional advisory board” means a public defender regional advisory board.
“Serious offense” means:

paragraph.text: a felony;
a misdemeanor or offense punishable by confinement for more than 3 months or a fine of more than $500;
a delinquent act that would be a serious offense if committed by an adult; or
an offense in which, in the opinion of the court, the complexity of the matter or the youth, inexperience, or mental capacity of the accused requires representation of the accused by an attorney.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 16–206 of this title, this title applies only to representation in or with respect to the courts of the State.
It is the policy of the State to:

paragraph.text: provide for the realization of the constitutional guarantees of counsel in the representation of indigent individuals, including related necessary services and facilities, in criminal and juvenile proceedings in the State;

assure the effective assistance and continuity of counsel to indigent accused individuals taken into custody and indigent individuals in criminal and juvenile proceedings before the courts of the State; and
authorize the Office of the Public Defender to administer and assure enforcement of this title.

section.text: There is an Office of the Public Defender in the Executive Branch of State government.

paragraph.text: The head of the Office is the Public Defender.
The Public Defender shall be appointed by the Board of Trustees.
By a vote of at least seven members, the Board of Trustees may remove the Public Defender for:

subparagraph.text: misconduct in office;
persistent failure to perform the duties of the Office; or
conduct prejudicial to the proper administration of justice.

paragraph.text: To qualify for appointment as Public Defender, an individual shall be an attorney admitted to practice law in the State by the Court of Appeals of Maryland who has engaged in the practice of law for at least 5 years before appointment.
The Public Defender shall receive the same salary as a judge of a circuit court.
The Public Defender may not engage in the private practice of law.
The Public Defender serves for a term of 6 years.
With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the Public Defender shall appoint:

subparagraph.text: a deputy public defender; and
one district public defender for each district of the District Court.

paragraph.text: The deputy public defender and each district public defender shall have the same qualifications as the Public Defender.
A district public defender shall:

subparagraph.text: assist the Public Defender to perform the duties of the Office; and
subject to the supervision of the Public Defender, be in charge of the public defender offices in the district for which the district public defender is appointed.

paragraph.text: With the advice of the district public defenders, the Public Defender may appoint assistant public defenders in accordance with the State budget.
To qualify for appointment as an assistant public defender, an individual shall be an attorney and admitted to practice law in the State by the Court of Appeals of Maryland.

subsection.text: The deputy public defender, district public defenders, and assistant public defenders:

paragraph.text: shall serve at the pleasure of the Public Defender; and
may not engage in the private practice of criminal law.

subsection.text: The Public Defender shall appoint investigators, stenographic assistants, clerical assistants, and other personnel as may be required to assist the Public Defender and the district public defenders to perform the duties of the Office in accordance with the State budget.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Public Defender shall establish and maintain suitable offices in the State.
At least one Public Defender’s office shall be in each district.

subsection.text: The number of positions, compensation, and expenses for the Office shall be in accordance with the State budget.

Representation of an indigent individual may be provided in accordance with this title by the Public Defender or, subject to the supervision of the Public Defender, by the deputy public defender, district public defenders, assistant public defenders, or panel attorneys.

paragraph.text: Indigent defendants or parties shall be provided representation under this title in:

subparagraph.text: a criminal or juvenile proceeding in which a defendant or party is alleged to have committed a serious offense;
a criminal or juvenile proceeding in which an attorney is constitutionally required to be present prior to presentment being made before a commissioner or judge;
a postconviction proceeding for which the defendant has a right to an attorney under Title 7 of this article;
any other proceeding in which confinement under a judicial commitment of an individual in a public or private institution may result;
a proceeding involving children in need of assistance under § 3–813 of the Courts Article; or
a family law proceeding under Title 5, Subtitle 3, Part II or Part III of the Family Law Article, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a parent, a hearing in connection with guardianship or adoption;
a hearing under § 5–326 of the Family Law Article for which the parent has not waived the right to notice; and
an appeal.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, representation shall be provided to an indigent individual in all stages of a proceeding listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection, including, in criminal proceedings, custody, interrogation, bail hearing before a District Court or circuit court judge, preliminary hearing, arraignment, trial, and appeal.
Representation is not required to be provided to an indigent individual at an initial appearance before a District Court commissioner.

section.text: Representation of an indigent individual by the Office or by a panel attorney shall continue until the final disposition of the case or until the assigned attorney is relieved by the Public Defender or order of the court in which the case is pending.

subsection.text: This title does not prohibit the Office from representing an indigent individual in federal court at federal expense if the matter arises out of or is related to an action pending or recently pending in a court of criminal jurisdiction of the State.

Compensation paid by the federal court to the Public Defender, the deputy public defender, a district public defender, or an assistant public defender shall be remitted to the General Fund of the State.
The primary duty of the Public Defender is to provide representation for indigent individuals in accordance with this title.
The Public Defender shall:

paragraph.text: be responsible generally for the operation of the Office and all district offices;

prepare schedules of professional fees and expenses for panel attorneys and other professional and technical services rendered to indigent individuals other than by the Public Defender’s staff, taking into consideration the nature of the services, the time spent, the skill or experience required, and any other pertinent factor;
consult and cooperate with professional groups about the causes of criminal conduct and the development of effective means to:

subparagraph.text: reduce and discourage the commission of crime;
rehabilitate and correct individuals charged and convicted of crime;
administer criminal justice; and
administer and conduct the Office; and

paragraph.text: maintain financial and statistical records about each case in which the Office provides legal assistance to an indigent individual, including data to calculate all direct and indirect costs to the Office.

subsection.text: The Public Defender may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out the purposes of this title and promote the efficient conduct of the work and general administration of the Office, its professional staff, and other employees;
make necessary arrangements to coordinate services of the Office with any federal program to provide an attorney to indigent individuals;
arrange for the Office to receive money or services available to assist in the duties under this title; and
accept the services of volunteer workers or consultants at no compensation or at nominal or token compensation and reimburse them for their necessary expenses.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, in Baltimore City, the Public Defender may contract with private or public organizations to provide legal, administrative, or technical services for indigent individuals.
A contract shall require that:

subparagraph.text: the level and quality of the work at least equal that of the Office; and
the Public Defender supervise and control all services rendered.

paragraph.text: Subject to the authority and supervision of the Public Defender, each district public defender shall maintain a confidential list of private attorneys available to be appointed as attorneys for indigent individuals eligible for representation under this title.
Each attorney on the list shall be:

subparagraph.text: admitted to practice law in the State; and
placed on various panels in accordance with qualification criteria that the Public Defender sets forth, based on:

sub-subparagraph.text: the nature and complexity of the offense requiring representation;
the trial or appellate experience of the attorney; and
any other factor necessary to ensure competent representation.

paragraph.text: Except in cases in which an attorney in the Office provides representation, the district public defender, subject to the supervision of the Public Defender, shall appoint an attorney from an appropriate panel to represent an indigent individual.
Panel attorneys shall be used as much as practicable.

The primary duty of a panel attorney is to the indigent individual represented by the panel attorney with the same effect and purpose as though privately engaged by that individual and without regard to the use of public funds to provide the service.
A panel attorney shall report to the Office as the regulations of the Public Defender require.
This subsection does not preclude the designation or assignment of different individuals to perform various parts of the service.

A panel attorney shall file a petition to be compensated by the Public Defender for fees and expenses incident to representing indigent individuals, including investigation, other pretrial preparation, trial, and appeal.
The Office shall authorize payment of fees and expenses according to schedules prepared under § 16–207(b)(2) of this subtitle and from funds appropriated by the State budget.
A panel attorney may not receive a fee for services in addition to that provided in accordance with this title.
To be compensated for fees or expenses that the Public Defender disapproves or that exceed those authorized for payment, a panel attorney may seek a review by a regional advisory board.
All fees and expenses paid to panel attorneys, including any authorized by a regional advisory board, shall be paid out of funds appropriated by the State budget.

subsection.text: The Office may provide staff and technical assistance to a panel attorney appointed to represent an indigent individual.

Communications between an indigent individual and an individual in the Office or engaged by the Public Defender are protected by the attorney–client privilege to the same extent as though an attorney had been privately engaged.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, this section does not preclude the Public Defender from using material in the Public Defender’s files that is otherwise privileged to prepare and disclose statistical, case study, and other sociological data.
Material used to prepare and disclose sociological data may not disclose the identity of a particular indigent individual.

subsection.text: An individual may apply for services of the Office as an indigent individual, if the individual states in writing under oath or affirmation that the individual, without undue financial hardship, cannot provide the full payment of an attorney and all other necessary expenses of representation in proceedings listed under § 16–204(b) of this subtitle.

For an individual whose assets and net annual income are less than 100 percent of the federal poverty guidelines, eligibility for services of the Office may be determined without an assessment regarding the need of the applicant.

paragraph.text: For an individual whose assets and net annual income equal or exceed 100 percent of the federal poverty guidelines, eligibility for the services of the Office shall be determined by the need of the applicant.
Need shall be measured according to the financial ability of the applicant to engage and compensate a competent private attorney and to provide all other necessary expenses of representation.
Financial ability shall be determined by:

subparagraph.text: the nature, extent, and liquidity of assets;
the disposable net income of the applicant;
the nature of the offense;
the length and complexity of the proceedings;
the effort and skill required to gather pertinent information; and
any other foreseeable expense.

paragraph.text: If eligibility cannot be determined before the Office or a panel attorney begins representation, the Office may represent an applicant provisionally.
If the Office subsequently determines that an applicant is ineligible:

subparagraph.text: the Office shall inform the applicant; and
the applicant shall be required to engage the applicant’s own attorney and reimburse the Office for the cost of the representation provided.

paragraph.text: The Office shall investigate the financial status of an applicant when the circumstances warrant.
The Office may:

subparagraph.text: require an applicant to execute and deliver written requests or authorizations that are necessary under law to provide the Office with access to confidential records of public or private sources that are needed to evaluate eligibility; and
on request, obtain information without charge from a public record office or other unit of the State, county, or municipal corporation.
The Office may submit requests to the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the Comptroller for information regarding the employment status and income of applicants.
Each request shall be accompanied by an authorization for release of information that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: in a form acceptable to the agency to which the request is submitted; and
signed by the applicant.

subparagraph.text: The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the Comptroller shall comply with requests for information made by the Office under this paragraph.
Requests and responsive information may be exchanged by facsimile transmission.

paragraph.text: If it appears that an indigent individual has or reasonably expects to have means to meet some of the expenses for services rendered, the indigent individual shall reimburse the Office:

subparagraph.text: by a single payment or in installments; and
in the amount that the indigent individual can reasonably be expected to pay.

paragraph.text: A default or failure by an indigent individual to make a payment may not affect the rendering of services to the indigent individual.

subsection.text: The Central Collection Unit of the Department of Budget and Management, on behalf of the Public Defender and in the name of the State, shall do all things necessary to collect all reimbursement money due to the State for services rendered in accordance with this title.

paragraph.text: A court exercising criminal jurisdiction shall order a defendant to reimburse the State for services rendered to the defendant by the Public Defender as a term or condition of a sentence, judgment, or probation imposed by the court, unless the court:

subparagraph.text: affirmatively finds that the defendant cannot make the reimbursement; and
waives the term or condition.

paragraph.text: The court shall establish the amount, time, and method of payment.
In all other cases of reimbursement for services rendered, collection shall be made in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

A court exercising other than criminal jurisdiction shall order an indigent individual represented by the Public Defender to reimburse the State for the reasonable value of services rendered to the indigent individual in an amount that the indigent individual may reasonably be able to pay.

If the indigent individual is a minor, the court shall order the parents, guardian, or custodian of the minor to reimburse the State for the reasonable value of services rendered in an amount that the parents, guardian, or custodian may reasonably be able to pay.
The court shall establish the amount, time, and method of payment.

subsection.text: Before ordering reimbursement under subsection (d) of this section, a court shall grant an opportunity to be heard to the indigent individual or the parents, guardian, or custodian of a minor.

The reasonable value of the services rendered to an indigent individual in accordance with this title is a lien on real or personal property in which the indigent individual has or acquires an interest, except for the residence of the indigent individual.

To perfect the lien, the Public Defender shall submit to the court having jurisdiction in the matter an affidavit setting forth the services rendered to the indigent individual and their reasonable value.

paragraph.text: The court shall set a hearing date and shall notify the indigent individual of the date and the fact that the Public Defender filed an affidavit to perfect the lien.
The indigent individual may:

subparagraph.text: appear;
be represented by an attorney;
present evidence; and
examine witnesses.

paragraph.text: The indigent individual may contest the affidavit.
If the court determines that the Public Defender is not entitled to a lien, the proceeding shall be dismissed.
If the court determines that the Public Defender is entitled to a lien, the court shall determine the reasonable value of the services rendered to the indigent individual.
On adjudication, a lien shall be filed or docketed with the clerk of the circuit court or District Court where the services were performed or where the indigent individual works or resides.
The lien shall:

subparagraph.text: constitute a lien on the indigent individual’s property for 10 years from the date of filing or docketing unless the lien is discharged sooner; and
have the force and effect of a judgment at law.
The clerks of the circuit courts and the District Court shall provide separate books to record liens under this section.
The books shall be properly indexed in the name of the debtor.
The Public Defender may not be required to pay filing or recording fees.

section.text: This subtitle does not prohibit the appointment of an attorney, other than through the Office, to represent an indigent individual by the District Court, a circuit court, or the Court of Special Appeals if:

paragraph.text: there is a conflict in legal representation in a matter involving multiple defendants, and one of the defendants is represented by or through the Office; or
the Office declines to provide representation to an indigent individual entitled to representation under this subtitle.

subsection.text: There is a Board of Trustees of the Office of the Public Defender.
The Board of Trustees consists of 13 members.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Board of Trustees shall be a resident of the State.
11 members of the Board of Trustees shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate and shall include a representative of each judicial circuit of the State.
All members of the Board of Trustees shall be active attorneys admitted to practice before the Court of Appeals of Maryland.
One member shall be appointed by the President of the Senate.
One member shall be appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates.
Each member appointed to the Board of Trustees shall:

subparagraph.text: have significant experience in criminal defense or other matters relevant to the work of the Board of Trustees; or
have demonstrated a strong commitment to quality representation of indigent defendants, including juvenile respondents.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board of Trustees may not be:

subparagraph.text: a current member or employee of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Judicial Branch; or
a law enforcement agency in the State; or
a State’s Attorney of a county or municipal corporation of the State;
the Attorney General of Maryland; or
the State Prosecutor.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member of the Board of Trustees is 3 years.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board of Trustees on October 1, 2010.
A vacancy occurring on the Board of Trustees during the term of a member shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as provided for appointments in this section.
At the end of a term a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member whose term has expired may be reappointed to the Board of Trustees.
The Board of Trustees annually shall elect a chair from among its members.
The chair shall preside over and represent the interests of the Board of Trustees in carrying out this title.

subsection.text: Seven members of the Board of Trustees are a quorum.

paragraph.text: The Board of Trustees shall hold at least one regular annual meeting at a time and place that the chair designates.
Additional meetings shall be held as necessary and may be called on notice by the chair or at the request of at least two members of the Board of Trustees.

subsection.text: A member of the Board of Trustees:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation for serving on the Board of Trustees; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Board of Trustees shall:

paragraph.text: study and observe the operation of the Office;
coordinate the activities of the regional advisory boards; and
advise the Public Defender on panels of attorneys, fees, and other matters about the operation of the public defender system.

subsection.text: There are four regional advisory boards of the Office.
Each regional advisory board consists of five members appointed by the Governor.
Of the four regional advisory boards:

paragraph.text: the first shall advise public defender districts one, eight, and nine, which encompass Baltimore City, Baltimore County, and Harford County;

the second shall advise public defender districts two and three, which encompass Caroline County, Cecil County, Dorchester County, Kent County, Queen Anne’s County, Somerset County, Talbot County, Wicomico County, and Worcester County;
the third shall advise public defender districts four, five, and seven, which encompass Anne Arundel County, Calvert County, Charles County, Prince George’s County, and St. Mary’s County; and

the fourth shall advise public defender districts six, ten, eleven, and twelve, which encompass Allegany County, Carroll County, Frederick County, Garrett County, Howard County, Montgomery County, and Washington County.

subsection.text: Each member of a regional advisory board shall be:

paragraph.text: a resident of a district represented by that regional advisory board; and

subparagraph.text: a judge of a circuit court;
a judge of the District Court; or
an active attorney admitted to practice before the Court of Appeals of Maryland.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of a regional advisory board is 3 years.
A vacancy occurring on a regional advisory board during the term of a member shall be filled by the Governor for the remainder of the unexpired term.
The Governor shall annually designate a chair of each regional advisory board from among the members of that regional advisory board.
The chair shall preside over and represent the interests of that regional advisory board in carrying out this title.

subsection.text: Three members of a regional advisory board are a quorum.

paragraph.text: Each regional advisory board shall hold at least one regular annual meeting at a time and place that the chair designates.
Additional meetings may be called:

subparagraph.text: on notice by the chair;
on notice by the Public Defender;
on notice by the district public defender from a district represented by that regional advisory board; or
at the request of at least three members of the regional advisory board.

subsection.text: A member of a regional advisory board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation for serving on the regional advisory board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: Each regional advisory board shall:

paragraph.text: study and observe the operation of district public defender offices; and
advise the Public Defender and district public defenders on panels of attorneys, fees, and other matters about the operation of district public defender offices and the public defender system.

subsection.text: On or before September 30 of each year, the Public Defender shall submit a report to:

paragraph.text: the Board of Trustees;
the Governor; and
in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

subsection.text: The report shall include:

paragraph.text: pertinent data about the operations of the Office, including projected needs, a breakdown of the number and type of cases handled, and relative dispositions; and
recommendations for statutory changes, including changes in the criminal law or Maryland Rules to control crime and improve the criminal justice system.

section.text: Funds for carrying out this title shall be as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The provisions of this title are severable.
The invalidity of a provision of this title does not affect other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid provision.
